description:
Lycorma delicatula, commonly known as the spotted lanternfly, is an invasive planthopper species native to parts of Asia, including China, India, and Vietnam. It belongs to the family Fulgoridae, which are known for their distinctive and often brightly colored wings.

The spotted lanternfly is a sap-feeding insect that targets a variety of plant species, including economically important crops and ornamental plants. It is particularly problematic due to its ability to cause significant damage to trees and vines, potentially leading to reduced yields and even plant mortality.

Adult spotted lanternflies are approximately 1 to 1.5 inches (25 to 38 millimeters) in length and have distinctive spotted wings. Their forewings are gray with black spots, while their hindwings are bright red with black spots. Nymphs, or immature stages, are black with white spots, transitioning to red with black and white spots as they develop.

The spotted lanternfly undergoes complete metamorphosis, with four nymphal stages preceding the adult form. It is known to feed on a wide range of host plants, including trees such as the tree of heaven (Ailanthus altissima), as well as various fruit trees, grapevines, and other woody plants.

This invasive species poses a significant threat to agricultural and forestry industries, and its rapid spread has led to increased monitoring and control efforts in areas where it has been detected. Ongoing research aims to better understand its biology, ecology, and potential management strategies to mitigate the impact of this invasive pest.
